The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

This is a piece of deceipt, like the reÅ¿t; for Robert Purnell, Robert SimpÅ¿on, and Richard Moon, who were the three MeÅ¿Å¿engers, to deÅ¿ire themÅ¿elves to anÅ¿wer, and preÅ¿ently put their hands to their own deÅ¿ires, with three more, two of which were never of the people with which I walked, and the other long Å¿ince removed his habitation near thirty miles diÅ¿tant. But however being by themÅ¿elves deÅ¿ired, becauÅ¿e they had none elÅ¿e, to deÅ¿ire it of them, they like themÅ¿elves begin to anÅ¿wer, and after many vain and idle words, they Å¿ay they received their commiÅ¿Å¿ion from God, to this worke, and met together, and conÅ¿idered the particulars, of which they were to admoniÅ¿h their backÅ¿lidden Brethren and SiÅ¿ters.

Reply. Here they blaÅ¿pheme the holy and dreadful name of God, by entituling it to their lies and Å¿landers, who never gave commiÅ¿Å¿ion to falÅ¿e Prophets, lyars and Å¿landerers, to admoniÅ¿h any of his, but reproved Å¿uch, Å¿aying, They run, and I Å¿ent them not, therefore they Å¿hall not profit the people: And Å¿o it is with you.

But from what did your brethren and Å¿iÅ¿ters, as ye call them, backÅ¿lide more than from your deceitfull wayes and practices, which to God are abhominable? If ye Å¿ay, it is from your outward fellowÅ¿hips, wayes, and worÅ¿hips, Then the ParÅ¿hes, from which ye have Å¿eparated your Å¿elves have the Å¿ame thing to admoniÅ¿h you of: And ye juÅ¿tifie thoÅ¿e filthy polluted PrieÅ¿ts, who caÅ¿t out the names or perÅ¿ons of Å¿ome from amongÅ¿t them,

becauÅ¿e they Å¿eparated themÅ¿elves from their polluted worÅ¿hips. BeÅ¿ides, one of the three Å¿aid, by faith he Å¿aw the downfall of all theÅ¿e Sects and Forms, and that it was not of Gods building, and that he Å¿aw ChriÅ¿t coming in Å¿pirit to deÅ¿troy it: And then how is it that ye are not aÅ¿hamed to Å¿ay, that to get out of that which God never built, is backÅ¿liding? And that God gave you a commiÅ¿sion to admoniÅ¿h any for departing out of that vvhich ChriÅ¿t in Å¿pirit came to deÅ¿troy. But your God (vvho is the God of the vvorld) that gave you Å¿uch a commiÅ¿Å¿ion, and put you upon thoÅ¿e vvorks of vvickedneÅ¿Å¿e is denied, together vvith your Å¿elves, vvho his CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners are, vvith all your pretended admonitions inventions and deceitfull Å¿tuffe, vvhich to the children of light are manifeÅ¿t, and Å¿een to be as light as vanitie.
They Å¿ay, They knew much themÅ¿elves, and what they knew not, they were fully Å¿atisfied by the mouths of many faithfull and true witneÅ¿Å¿es.
Reply. Where were they found? in many particulars, Å¿ithence ye are already proved an unfaithfull company of lyars and deceitful workers.
They Å¿ay, In the name of the Lord, and in obedience to his command, and in a filial feare to God, love and pity to our Å¿ouls, they did admoniÅ¿h, &c.

Reply Did they know the name of the Lord, which is dreadfull to all deceivers, falÅ¿e prophets, and hypocrites, they would not dare to name it, whiles they live in iniquity; but out of his name are ye all Å¿hut, and have no portion in that which is a Å¿trong tower, to which the righteous run, and are Å¿aved. Who for your rebellion and diÅ¿obedience againÅ¿t his name (who live out of his feare) which is the light of the world, are by the light judged and condemned,
who in your vaine mindes talk of love and pirty to Å¿oules, but never came to witneÅ¿Å¿e the living Å¿oul, nor the quickning Å¿pirit, where the true love and pity comes to be witneÅ¿Å¿ed.

But did your three MeÅ¿Å¿engers in the name, and in the fear, and in obedience to the Lord admoniÅ¿h? How then came it to paÅ¿Å¿e, that they came to a near relation of mine, and told her, in the name of the Lord, &c they were Å¿ent to admoniÅ¿h her alÅ¿o of Å¿omething, as Å¿in. To which Å¿he replyed to Robert SimpÅ¿on that Å¿pake, HaÅ¿t not thou Å¿omething in thee that tells thee thou doÅ¿t lye in the name of the Lord? For, what Å¿in do I live in which thou knoweÅ¿t? To which he Å¿aid; Dear Å¿iÅ¿ter, I doe not Å¿ay, in practice, but in judgement. To which Å¿he replying, What is my judgement? CanÅ¿t thou tell? He appeared confounded, and Å¿aid, Doe not you heare thoÅ¿e men (meaning thoÅ¿e called Quakers) Now is not here deceit and wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, to pretend to admoniÅ¿h people in the name, fear, and obedience of God, and at laÅ¿t know not for what, but aske if Å¿he did not hear thoÅ¿e men, which Robert SimpÅ¿on himÅ¿elf had often done (it's like more often than Å¿he at that time.) Now have ye not read that God is not mocked? but what ye Å¿owe, the Å¿ame yee muÅ¿t reape. Why then doe yee thus to the fleÅ¿h Å¿owe corruption, falÅ¿hood, lying and deceit, and make mention of the name of the Lord as your covering?

To what they Å¿aid to me in particular, I need not Å¿ay much, becauÅ¿e what I Å¿aid before Å¿tands unanÅ¿wered, and in power over your heads, only they Å¿ay, the things they charged me withal are true, every Å¿yllable, as appears by the foregoing anÅ¿wer of the whole Church, which is falÅ¿e, and thoÅ¿e they call the Church proved lyars: And whereas they Å¿ay, they did not feare me, neither did their conÅ¿ciences accuÅ¿e them. In this they preÅ¿ently gave themÅ¿elves the lie, and Å¿ay the reaÅ¿on they Å¿taid not was, becauÅ¿e they found my Å¿pirit the time before as a boyling fornace boyling over, and Å¿calding all that Å¿tand near it, which made them reÅ¿olve not to Å¿tay the Å¿econd time. Now what deceit and wickedneÅ¿Å¿e is here? Who can believe a word that comes from amongÅ¿t you, who are out of the feare of God, and therefore regard not what ye Å¿ay. For I having charged them in my laÅ¿t, that they fled as men Å¿urprized with feare, or accuÅ¿ed by their own conÅ¿ciences: They deny it, and Å¿ay it is falÅ¿e, and that they neither feared me, nor were accuÅ¿ed, &c. And yet in 6. or 8, lines have fully granted what I Å¿aid, Å¿aying the reaÅ¿on they Å¿taid not, was becauÅ¿e they found my Å¿prrit as a boyling fornace, boyling over and Å¿calding, &c. Now is it not evident, they feared leÅ¿t they Å¿hould be Å¿calded? and what was there that Å¿calded, but the witneÅ¿Å¿e of God within themÅ¿elves? Poor men! I knew they were wounded, tormented, and Å¿calded by the witneÅ¿s of God, in their own conÅ¿ciences, teÅ¿tifying againÅ¿t their hypocriÅ¿ie and deceit, Å¿o that they could not Å¿tand, nor abide it; for the day of the Lord is now great, and who may abide it; for it is like refiners fire, yea it burns as an oven, and all that doe wickedly are as Å¿tubble, and not onely Å¿calded, but burned muÅ¿t ye be, and neither root nor branch Å¿hall be left. And the falÅ¿e Prophets that Å¿ee vanity, and divine lies, and all that imbrace and receive them, who muÅ¿t not be in the aÅ¿Å¿embles of Gods people, are not in a capacity (as they Å¿ay) for thoÅ¿e that feare the name of the Lord, to converÅ¿e withall. Neither is dried Å¿tubble in a capacity to contend with thoÅ¿e in whom the Å¿pirit of judgment and burning is, left thereby they be both Å¿calded and burned.

But Robert Purnell and Robert SimpÅ¿on, were it not meet for you to take liced, & beware, leÅ¿t (whiles ye pretend a CommiÅ¿Å¿ion from God, to admoniÅ¿h others for backÅ¿liding, who are not at all drawn back, but are of thoÅ¿e that believe, to the Å¿alvation of their Å¿ouls, who for the hope Å¿et before them, doe endure the CroÅ¿Å¿e, & deÅ¿piÅ¿e the Å¿hame, and with much patience, through many tribulations, the race doe run, and through good report, and evil report, as deceivers, and yet true, do paÅ¿Å¿e, preÅ¿sing on, if by any meanes they may attain to the reÅ¿urrection of the dead, and to apprehend that for which they are apprehended of ChriÅ¿t JeÅ¿us.) Ye your Å¿elves be not found in Satans work, and indeed gone back, by many degrees into the world, and the pollutions thereof, being intangled and overcome by that which once ye Å¿eemed in a meaÅ¿ure to have eÅ¿caped, and Å¿o your latter end become worÅ¿e then your beginning. And therefore to you, or to one of you I Å¿ay, do not eate and drinke with the drunken, do not fill your Å¿elves with wine and ftrong drink, nor Å¿pend the creation of God upon your luÅ¿ts: Do not Å¿pend your time out of the feare of the Lord, in pleaÅ¿ure and wantonneÅ¿Å¿e, in lightneÅ¿Å¿e and vanity, abuÅ¿ing the Å¿ervants of the Lord, For he is at the door, and ye know him not, that will cut you aÅ¿under (except ye repent) and all your inventions, traditions, fooliÅ¿h cuÅ¿tomes, and carnall waÅ¿hings, will not hide nor help you: And this is a warning to thoÅ¿e of you that forget God, and caÅ¿t his law, which is light, behinde your backs, to conÅ¿ider, leÅ¿t he teare you in pieces, and there be none to deliver you, who as unÅ¿avourie Å¿alt are become, whoÅ¿e ill Å¿avour is gone abroad from AlehouÅ¿es and Taverns (too much frequented) Å¿porting your Å¿elves with the enemies of God, with which ye now begin to appear as one, rather than to be grieved for the afflictions of JoÅ¿eph, or to become companions of thoÅ¿e, who for witneÅ¿Å¿ing the power and life of JeÅ¿us, do Å¿uffer by the world, the generation of Vipers, as ever they did of old. And this is all the fruit I know that your invented waÅ¿hings have brought you to, and yet for this time I do very much Å¿pare one of you.

But why are Robert SimpÅ¿on and Thomas Ewins Å¿o much troubled, that my letters to each of them are made publique; for what is publiÅ¿hed was written to them many moneths before, without an intent to publiÅ¿h it, and in all that time, which one of them acknowledgeth, was above a yeare, no anÅ¿wer was given in word or writing, nor any word Å¿poken to me about it by them, teÅ¿tifying diÅ¿like, as if all were quiet and well. But now it's made publique, and brought to light, and their deeds Å¿een and openly reproved, how angry do they appear, crying out of wrong, lies, &c. and after me pour their floods of contempt, reproach and Å¿corn, notwithÅ¿tanding, under their hands it may appear, I was before called their honoured Brother, and when of worldly honours I could accept (though I did not, as others Å¿eek it) and when into his mouth I could freely put, Thomas Ewins to me cryed peace, and in my abÅ¿ence declared he had little or no encouragement to abide in BriÅ¿tol, were it not for me But Å¿ince to the light I have been turned, and by it convinced of the blindneÅ¿s and falÅ¿eneÅ¿s of your minds and worÅ¿hips, and could not put into his mouth, as before, hovv doth he bite with the teeth, and prepare war againÅ¿t me, though his weapons appear too weak and carnall to prevail, againÅ¿t which the bowe is in Å¿trength; and the Reader, whoÅ¿e eyes are opened, will eaÅ¿ily perceive, that had not the things been true, which to each of them I writ, and not at all to be gainÅ¿aid, nor contradicted, they would in all that time, either in
words or writing, plead their own innocency againÅ¿t me, who had Å¿o much wronged them as now they pretend: But being very true, and not to be gainÅ¿aid, the Å¿ubtileÅ¿t beaÅ¿t in the field (it's like) perÅ¿wades them to be quiet, that it be not noiÅ¿ed abroad, but in oblivion kept: But Å¿ince, beyond their expectation it is come to light, and they cannot prevent it; Å¿ome courÅ¿e (if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible) muÅ¿t be taken, that it be not believed. And therefore (how falÅ¿ly Å¿oever accuÅ¿ed) it muÅ¿t be of lyes, falÅ¿hood, and folly, though themÅ¿elves feel the power of it, Å¿tanding in truth and wiÅ¿dome, and have not told the Reader in what the folly and falÅ¿hood lies: But (by all the means they are able) labour to recover a veil, though but little have either they or you done, more then to enÅ¿nare your Å¿elves in your own vvorks, whoÅ¿e webb is not become a garment, neither do your works profit, for your works are works of vanity: But how comes it to paÅ¿Å¿e, that my letters were true, and not to be contradicted before they vvere publiÅ¿hed, but are not Å¿o novv? Why onely thus, our skirts are diÅ¿covered, our Å¿epulchre is opened, and our nakedneÅ¿Å¿e is novv made manifeÅ¿t, that people (as vve paÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿treet) point us out Notorious, and at us vvag the head; Å¿o that before the people (that are not vvilfully blinde) vve and our povverleÅ¿s, hypocritical profeÅ¿Å¿ion (vvhich Å¿tands in vvords and forms, not in Å¿pirit and povver) are like to receive but little honour.

Novv becauÅ¿e they have vvritten Å¿everally, I Å¿hall reply particularly: And firÅ¿t to Robert SimpÅ¿on, in vvhom (me thinks) I Å¿ee moÅ¿t honeÅ¿ty, though it be clouded and covered vvith much deceit and hypocriÅ¿ie, vvhich the light reproves: And had I not a deÅ¿ire very much to Å¿pare him, for the honeÅ¿ties Å¿ake, the Å¿econd Å¿troak vvould exceed the firÅ¿t: And becauÅ¿e I perceive his main vvork (as vvell as yours) is to Å¿eek a veile of deceipt, under vvhich to hide himÅ¿elfe from the Å¿troke of truth, and to attain it, Å¿pends himÅ¿elfe in many light, vaine, and angry words, which have little weight, I Å¿hall not trouble my Å¿elfe, nor the Reader in Å¿peaking much to it, for of it Å¿elfe it falls, yet I would not that he Å¿hould Å¿o often take the name of the Lord in vaine, as he doth in the beginning of what he Å¿peaks, for the Lord will not hold him guiltleÅ¿s. But in page 29. he Å¿aith, If the charge I laid upon him were Å¿o indeed, how Å¿ad were his condition? Well might his countenance be changed, and his thoughts trouble him.

To which I reply, That though he hath laboured till (he Å¿aith) he hath forgotten himÅ¿elfe, to vindicate or cover himÅ¿elf from what was truly laid upon him, yet from it hath he not delivered himÅ¿elfe, but the charge Å¿tands good, in Å¿ound and Å¿ober words, in the power of truth, and whiles he covereth his Å¿in be cannot proÅ¿per. And whiles he addeth one iniquity to another, he cannot come into Gods righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e: And oh! that he would conÅ¿ider it, and lay it to heart whiles he hath time, that in the day of the Lords anger, which is at hand, and as a deÅ¿truction from the Almighty Å¿hall come, he might be hid and find mercy of the Lord, with whom his vain Å¿peaking of a witneÅ¿Å¿e he hath in heaven brought from thence into his heart, and confirmed by the Spirit of Truth, and of his being taken up into the Mount to confer with him, who hath all power given him and of a Warrant Å¿ealed and given forth from him that hath al power, &c. is of little accompt, whiles he underÅ¿tands not what he Å¿peaks; For the Kingdom of God cometh not with obÅ¿ervation, but the kingdome of
God is within, and in his Kingdom he is who dwells in heaven, where the Father, the Word and Spirit agree, of which all blind PhariÅ¿aical ProfeÅ¿Å¿ors are ignorant and cannot know it, till in the light, and by the Å¿pirit it be revealed and made manifeÅ¿t.

And whereas he Å¿aith, All that he, with the reÅ¿t, laid at my door, was to a tittle true; and that neither he nor his brethren have any reluctance for it. This is all falÅ¿, for I have before proved it lies and deceit, and themÅ¿elves have confeÅ¿t they found that which boiled like a furnace, and Å¿calded all that Å¿tand near it, and they were near it, and Å¿o reÅ¿olved not to Å¿tay another time. And judgement is now laid to the line, and righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s to the plummet, and all refuges of lies and deceit are to be Å¿wept away, and by truth and Å¿oberneÅ¿s Å¿uch hiding places are overflown, and in Å¿oberneÅ¿s do I Å¿tand; and Å¿o much to my Å¿elf am I come, that I Å¿ee many of his words there mentioned to veil and cover himÅ¿elf, to be light and vain, and not worth anÅ¿wering, and that what I writ, was both Å¿ober and true, without fawning and flattery, in which many among you are too much exerciÅ¿ed, who love to have Å¿mooth, not true things Å¿poken, and would have me peaceable, gentle, and full of mercy to hypocriÅ¿ie, deceit and wickedneÅ¿s, all which is for judgement, and no peace from God is Å¿poken to it. And therefore without partiality do I declare againÅ¿t it in him and you, as well as in others, and to my Å¿elf am I not a Å¿tranger. And this is pure wiÅ¿dom from above, and moderation, known unto all that receive and believe in the light, by which that Å¿pirit appearing in my former book, is juÅ¿tified, though to you that hate the light, and by the light are condemned it is as gall and wormword. And for Å¿porting my Å¿elf, and inÅ¿ulting over him; I did it not, but it is another refuge of lies; for I told him before, I did not inÅ¿ult over him, nor delight in his wo and miÅ¿ery, but was Å¿orely grieved, as Å¿till I am, to Å¿ee how the wicked one, whom the Lord would deÅ¿troy, was exalted in him and you, and what I writ is true. And whereas he Å¿aith, I was not a in a Å¿ober mind, but at a diÅ¿tance from it, and true Å¿peaking (when I mentioned to him the portion of lyars) and that not any thing he Å¿aid was a lie, but what he Å¿aid I had not his hand to, as his particular affirmation; and Å¿o goes on Å¿peaking many words, but to what purpoÅ¿e I cannot Å¿ee, except it be by words to darken the Readers underÅ¿tanding. But if I miÅ¿take not, that which he would do, is to vindicate himÅ¿elf from being a lyar, with what elÅ¿e I charged upon him in my former Letter, by telling me he Å¿aid I had not his hand to it, as his particular accuÅ¿ation. And if this be his meaning, then is it groÅ¿s deceit, for I never Å¿aid or thought it was his particular accuÅ¿ation, but a general accuÅ¿ation delivered by him, in which himÅ¿elf and each other particular, was included, and Å¿o I Å¿pake to him in Å¿oberneÅ¿s and pitty, my very howels moving towards him, knowing my Å¿elf innocent, and that it was a dreadful thing for him in the Name or the Lord to Å¿peak a falÅ¿e viÅ¿ion or thing. I asked him, how he durÅ¿t come to me, and in the name of the Lord tell me, I Å¿aid the Scriptures of truth were one of the greateÅ¿t plagues of the land, when I never Å¿pake nor thought Å¿uch a thing. To which he replyed, he never Å¿pake it, nor laid it to my charge, though out of his own mouth it came; and when I told him I had it under his hand, he denyed it. When I told him I could Å¿hew it him, he replied, if I could, he would acknowledge himÅ¿elf a lyar; upon which ground I charged him for it as before, and Å¿o I do Å¿till, and good were it for him, if he owned
the judgement and repented, for otherwiÅ¿e he cannot eÅ¿cape. But if he forgeting that his hand was to his paper, did run himÅ¿elf into the evil of denying it, as is before expreÅ¿t; yet if (when he came to the Å¿ight of his error) he had clearly acknowledged it, and owned his condemnation and repented, to which in love he was adviÅ¿ed, there had been mercy for him: but being convinced and reproved of the evil, hardened his neck, and labours to hide and cover his Å¿in, adding one iniquity unto another; here he cannot proÅ¿per, but brings himÅ¿elf juÅ¿tly under, not onely the judgement and condemnation mentioned in my former Letter, but more and more miÅ¿ery due to thoÅ¿e that rebel againÅ¿t the light, by which they are reproved, and to thoÅ¿e that add iniquity unto iniquity, and muÅ¿t not come into Gods righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s. And from it all the waters in Jordan can never waÅ¿h him, not the Rocks and Mountains cover him, nor all your outward obÅ¿ervations, imaginations and willworÅ¿hips, preÅ¿erve him, till he own the light, by which he is convinced and reproved, and the juÅ¿t condemnation thereof paÅ¿s upon the rebellious, and the tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿or which hath Å¿inned, and he brought to repentance, and the acknowledgement of the truth; and Å¿o his Å¿oul come to be Å¿aved in this mighty day of the Lords power. And this is not from a violent heat of wild-fire, as he calls it, but from a Å¿pirit of Å¿oberneÅ¿s, Å¿oundneÅ¿s and truth, and is true love to his Å¿oul; and the time is near, in which he that rebuketh plainly Å¿hall find more favour then he that flattereth with his lips, and my end is not to make him a tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿or before all, as he Å¿uppoÅ¿eth, but according to my meaÅ¿ure to adviÅ¿e him, into the way, the light, the life and the truth, which leadeth out of tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion, into the inheritance of the Saints in light; and in this I do not equivocate, nor evade, as he falÅ¿ely chargeth me, but do Å¿peak plainly and truly, though at it, both he and ye are offended. And both BaptiÅ¿m and the Lords Supper I do own, as before I Å¿aid; and all your traditions, imaginations, inventions carnal obÅ¿ervations and will-worÅ¿hips I do deny, who in the many things (about which ye are troubled) oftend all, and are not come to the one BaptiÅ¿m, by which the Saints were baptized into one body; nor know not the Cup of the New TeÅ¿tament, nor the bread of life, which is the life of men, nor the fruit of the Vine, of which ChriÅ¿t with his DiÅ¿ciples drank new in his Fathers Kingdom; and Å¿o are feeding your Å¿elves with that which will never Å¿atisfie, but is corruptible, and muÅ¿t periÅ¿h in the uÅ¿ing. And the ground on which ye Å¿tand and queÅ¿tion me is not good, but of God is rejected, and bryars and thorns doth it bring forth, and its near unto curÅ¿ing. And whereas he Å¿aith, though he was not preÅ¿ent when I Å¿pake Å¿o reproachfully of the Scriptures, yet he did believe it, and Å¿till doth.

I Reply, Here is plainly, and without equivocation, as he calls it, the ground of your lies and Å¿landers, falÅ¿e accuÅ¿ations and charges, as well as of your windy, heady, and powerleÅ¿s Religion, (that is to Å¿ay) your believing things, which ye neither heard nor Å¿aw, but have got by tradition and hearÅ¿ay from others, as he confeÅ¿Å¿eth of himÅ¿elf in this particular, and few can believe it beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e that are given over to believe lyes, becauÅ¿e there is no truth at all in it. And although he Å¿aith, I had not his hand in particular, to what he heard not, yet I know I had it to the whole, of which that is a part; and I have it to that which he denies, and Å¿aith, I had it not; and well was it that I had it under hand, or elÅ¿e how Å¿tiffely would it be denyed and gainÅ¿ayed, as it
was directly at firÅ¿t, and after plain conviction, what Å¿huffling and deceit is here uÅ¿ed amongÅ¿t you, to hide and cover it, though to little purpoÅ¿e? And had I not by the wiÅ¿dom of God, had a Coppy of your charge, Å¿igned by Å¿ome of your Å¿elves, how muÅ¿t all your lyes and forged accuÅ¿ations (which ye publiÅ¿h and Å¿ay was verbatim, and proved to a tittle and Å¿yllable) paÅ¿s for truth, becauÅ¿e ye Å¿ay it is Å¿o, which by the Å¿aid Coppy is proved not verbatim, nor is proved true, but the contrary.

And whereas Robert SimpÅ¿on declares I had no ground at all, to lay that agravavation of lying upon him, viz. a lye invented, a lye proÅ¿ecuted, a lye denyed, and the lye proved, and afterwards adviÅ¿eth me not to evade nor equivocate, but Å¿peak truly, and deal plainly.

Reply. I have before dealt Å¿o truly and plainly, without flattery, that ye are offended, yet I Å¿hall take his adviÅ¿e, and plainly declare, the lye was invented amongÅ¿t you, when ye Å¿tudied your accuÅ¿ations, the lye was proÅ¿ecuted by your MeÅ¿Å¿engers, who charged me with the guilt of what ye had falÅ¿ely contrived. The lye was denyed by Robert SimpÅ¿on, when he denied that he Å¿pake Å¿uch a thing, or laid it to my charge, though I had it under his hand; and the lye by me Å¿tands proved, both on you and him, from which ye can never deliver your Å¿elves by all your Å¿hifting and Å¿triving, but like a bird in the Å¿nare, the more ye Å¿trive, the more ye are intangled, till ye acknowledge your iniquitie, and own your condemnation, and repent. And Å¿o Robert SimpÅ¿ons weapons being but the wrath and deceivableneÅ¿s of man, and not under promiÅ¿e of a bleÅ¿Å¿ing from God, are found too carnal (as he acknowledgeeth) to war againÅ¿t the Lamb and his followers, whoÅ¿e weapons are not carnal like his, but mighty, thorough God, to the pulling down, and laying low all high things, Å¿o that no lying refuges, nor deceitful coverings, are able to Å¿tand. But the Armies of the world, who follow the beaÅ¿t, to make war with the Lamb, do flie and fall before them. Glory to him that Å¿its upon the throne, and to the Lamb for evermore.

div.head: A Reply to Thomas Ewins his word, as he calls it.
div.p: I Find Thomas Ewins, in the beginning of his word, as he calls it, acknowledging the receipt of my Letter above a year Å¿ince, never intending to anÅ¿wer it; but Å¿ince it is publiÅ¿hed, takes himÅ¿elf bound to anÅ¿wer, and makes uÅ¿e of Solomons words, to cover his deceitful pretences, juÅ¿t like one whom God abhors, which teacheth for hire, and devineth for money, and corrupteth the Scriptures, with which he trades; for doth he not know that the true reaÅ¿on of his intending never to anÅ¿wer, was (not leÅ¿t he Å¿hould be like unto me, as he pretends, but rather) knowing the guilt, dreaded the conteÅ¿t, and would gladly bury it in Å¿ilence; but being made publique, holds himÅ¿elf bound to anÅ¿wer, not leÅ¿t I be wiÅ¿e, &c. but leÅ¿t (his wickedneÅ¿s and deceit being made manifeÅ¿t, and he proved out of the wayes, and out of the life of the MiniÅ¿ters of ChriÅ¿t, and in the wayes and Å¿teps of thoÅ¿e MaÅ¿ters, whoÅ¿e gain came in by devination) he in this might Å¿uffer loÅ¿s, and accompt himÅ¿elf bound to prevent it; and by Å¿orcery and wicked art, makes uÅ¿e of Solomons words as his covering.
